content.intro:
As the Neapolitans say, “Vedi Napoli e poi muori!” (“See Naples and die!”). Succumb to the splendour of the Gulf of Naples and the unrivalled attractions of the ancient city.

The mythical “journey to Naples” has always evoked emotions and dreams: a great escape in the cradle of Western culture with the Mediterranean Sea and splendour of the surrounding islands on the horizon. Gaze ahead, sit back and relax, carried by the invigorating flow of one of the largest cities in the Mediterranean.

The capital of Campania is home to three million people who highly cherish their traditions, while remaining open to rest of the world. Cultural life is intense and feeds the rich past of the castles, palaces, villas, churches, monasteries and museums who compete for this holiday destination of the ancient Romans. The vast historic centre, designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1995, boasts unrivalled archaeological treasures.

Far from falling asleep on its prestigious achievements, the city plays the card of progress and innovation: there Apple opened its first school for computer programmers, the network of shared electric cars continues to grow and the new metro system, at the cutting edge of technology, has 16 stations designed as works of art, a project at the forefront of urban architecture.

The Neapolitan good life is distinguished by its world-renowned cuisine. Famous for its pizza, of course, nearly as highly regarded as a national monument, gives pride of place to local products: vegetables are grown in abundance and tomatoes, another landmark of the region, are among the best in Italy. The nearby sea inspires soups and fritto misti (fried seafood and small fish). To experience another pride of the regional gastronomy, taste the unmatchable mozzarella di buffalo of Campania, nicknamed oro bianco (white gold). That says it all!

A few dozen kilometres from the centre, while nature reclaims its rights on the remarkable site of Pompeii, the fumaroles of Vesuvius are a reminder that the giant is still dormant, but that doesn't undermine the constant good humour of the Neapolitans.

Nestled in the hollow of its dazzling gulf, the radiant city will offer you the most pleasant of stays. Between history and modernity, cultural heritage and everyday pleasures, set out to discover the Neapolitan lifestyle, “right under the sun!”

content.title: Dive into a Roman Atlantis

introduction.small: Already a spa resort during Roman times, and a favourite among the rich and powerful, Baia was engulfed by rising waters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dive into a Roman Atlantis

paragraphs.text:
Put on your wetsuit and fins and plunge (quite literally!) into the role of an archaeologist while exploring the Baia submerged park. About 30 kilometres from Naples, what used to be a vacation resort for the Roman elite is now under sea level. Whether you love snorkelling or scuba diving, you will turn into a marine Indiana Jones. Swim for ruin to ruin and visit this submarine city, looking for remnants of frescoes, mosaics and even entire villas, like Emperor Claudius' Nymphea, or the ruins of the “Villa a Protiro” with its huge black and white tiled floor that have been completely preserved. Explore forward the baths, which foundations are still visible. Engulfed by Poseidon, the place appears timeless, stuck forever in its old self. It reminds dreamers of what is left of ancient lost city. Shoals of fish navigate the old statues covered in seaweed (some new ones are actually copies) and broken pottery. Witness their graceful dance around the site, like the gatekeepers of mythical Atlantis.

Beware, the place is particularly vulnerable: just like at the museum, it should be noted the show is for your eyes only, and it is forbidden to touch anything. The visit will thus remain unspoilt for the next visitors!

Baia submerged archaeological park
Via Lucullo 94
80070 Bacoli

+39 081 523 2739

https://www.pafleg.it/it/4388/localita/52/parco-sommerso

content.title: Caesar Augustus: eyes to the sea

introduction.small: Steps away from Axel Munthe's Villa San Michele, in Anacapri, this Relais & Châteaux-listed luxury hotel offers imperial comfort amid the splendour of its panoramic vistas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Caesar Augustus: eyes to the sea

paragraphs.text:
Take the hydrofoil boat from the port of Naples to Capri and climb to the Hotel Caesar Augustus, clinging to the cliff, in Anacapri. The magnificence of the gardens is equalled only by the breath-taking view over the Bay of Naples. Here you will feel like Tiberius, perched on the rock with eyes glued to the sea, as you lounge on the terrace or luxuriate in the infinity-edge pool. The gastronomic cuisine is naturally oriented around olive oil, the morning's catch, and the herbs and vegetables grown in the hotel's own organic garden or taken from around the Bay of Naples, Vesuvius, and the Sorrento peninsula. Yoga courses at the spa, tennis, fishing, scuba diving, water skiing, and sailing are all available. This is an earthly paradise where King Farouk, in his time, reserved his suite by the year.

Caesar Augustus
Via Giuseppe Orlandi 4
80071 Anacapri

+39 (0)81 837 3395

https://www.caesar-augustus.com/

Room : from 390 EUR

content.title: The Naples Metro, a true work of art

introduction.small: Considered as veritable artistic works, certain stations of Lines 1 and 6 of the Neapolitan metro will amaze you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Naples Metro, a true work of art

paragraphs.text:
Never will the desire to take the metro be as strong as it is at Naples. You will even want to go down to the city's underground just to admire the fantastic decor. Indeed, 15 stations of Line 1 (Garibaldi, Università, Dante, Vanvitelli) nicknamed ‘Metro of the Arts' and a few on Line 6 (Mergellina, Augusto, Lala and Mostra) welcome onlookers, impressed by so much creativity. These art galleries have come into being thanks to a hundred artists, designers and architects, such as Alessandro Mendini, Karim Rashid, Anish Kapoor and Sol LeWitt. More than 200 works were spread out among the different stations that you can admire with the modest price of a metro ticket. Considered one of ‘Europe's Most Impressive Underground Railway Stations' the Toledo stop which was designed by creators on the theme of water and light, has two impressive blue-toned mosaics with LED panels that are set off by your passage. A veritable sensorial and aesthetic experience.

Metro lines 1 & 6
Napoli

www.anm.it

content.title: The Gulf of Naples, land of fire and water

introduction.small: A maritime treasure opening onto the Tyrrhenian sea, the Gulf of Naples extends to the Sorrento peninsula. A little visit of the Campania region, perfumed by volcanic scents.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Gulf of Naples, land of fire and water

paragraphs.text:
You can have a spectacular view of the Gulf of Naples from Miseno just outside of Naples, a former Roman military port that became a holiday destination for wealthy members of the Empire. Lined by the light-coloured facades of Neapolitan houses, the gulf extends its sapphire waters all the way to the foot of Mount Vesuvius, dormant since its last eruption in 1944. Escape from Naples and its incessant tumult,and take the boat to Ischia or Procida (showcasing their blue caves) or the road to the Sorrento Peninsula then a ferry to the touristy yet gorgeous island of Capri. Contemplate, with the sweet sound of cicadas, the wild inlets with terraces, villas and castles hidden behind the green foliage of lemon trees and vines. Though silent, Vesuvius is eyeing you with its fiery gaze. Campania, dotted with charming little villages and rich Mediterranean vegetation, immerses you in the history and traditions of one of the most beautiful regions of the country.

Naples tourist office
Galleria Umberto I 27
80132 Napoli
+39 081 402 394

https://www.visitnaples.eu/en

content.title: Libreria Berisio, literature, glass in hand

introduction.small: Used books and Italian wine are the concept of this alternative and cosy bookshop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Libreria Berisio, literature, glass in hand

paragraphs.text:
The windows of Libreria Berisio shows their hand from the street. The plethora of used books of all kinds provoke you to push the door open. There, the magic begins immediately.

Weathered and warm, the interior exudes tranquillity with its worn and welcoming armchairs and bar behind, which proudly places wines whose names alone invite you on a wine trip (with moderation), nonetheless literary (without limitation). Aglianico, Cannonau, Montepulciano, Negroamaro…

The journey will take place between Sicily, Apulia and Tuscany, at the discretion of the wine authors' pages, or elsewhere.

Here, nothing is free but everything is reasonable: books are not to browse but to buy at a low price; the wine, served by the glass or bottle, is sold at a reasonable price. Now you're ready to begin the evening with Italo Calvino, with the sound of good jazz or live music on the weekends, a perfect location to take a break from the city's frenzy for a moment.

Libreria Berisio
Via Port'Alba 28
80134 Napoli

+39 081 549 9090

https://www.facebook.com/Berisio

Menu: 5 EUR a glass of wine (20 EUR a bottle)

content.title: Pintauro, a love for puff pastry

introduction.small: Naples' historic bakery, Pintauro, creates sfogliatelle that are to die for. When "institution" rhymes with "passion".

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pintauro, a love for puff pastry

paragraphs.text:
Pushing open the door of Pintauro brings you 230 years back in time. Here, in this bakery all dressed in marble, is where the famous sfogliatella was born. A puff pastry cone, stuffed with vanilla- or cinnamon-flavoured ricotta, sfogliatella has done as much for Campania's recognition as the tomato or tarantella. Add some candied fruit, take a bite and look up to thank heaven for bringing you to Via Toledo.

Served hot or cold, the Pintauro's sfogliatelle compete for the title of best sfogliatelle in the city with those produced by Scaturchio (Piazza San Domenico Maggiore).

For over two centuries, foodies and fans of these sweets sprinkled with icing sugar, flood into this pastecerria. Take your pick between the rum baba, a ricotta-filled cannolo or zeppole stuffed with custard. You can never have too much of a good thing; greedily jump in line to reach your Holy Grail!

Pintauro
Via Toledo 275
80132 Napoli

+39 081 417 339

Menu: around 2,50 EUR for a sfogiatella

content.title: Friggitoria Vomero, fritters on the run

introduction.small: Friggitoria Vomero offers an infinite variety of light and refined fried treats. Don't believe it? Try for yourself!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Friggitoria Vomero, fritters on the run

paragraphs.text:
The Vomero district invites you to discover the chic and residential Naples. Throughout its climbing streets are hidden treasures like Friggitoria Vomero, a deli that offers snacks to devour on the spot or to take away.
Minimalist decor contrasts with the generous gourmet cuisine. In no particular order, choose from crostone (thin slices of garnished toast), pizze ricotta and salame, mozzarella, scarola and prosciutto, as well as melanzane fritters (made with aubergine), prepared before your eyes. The classic Neapolitan pizza and the crocchè potato and egg fritters are to try. Your taste buds will tell you to come back for more and more. The frying is light, crispy…
Friggitoria Vomero's secret? Since Friggitoria opened in 1938, the Acunzo family has preciously preserved it and the establishment's success remains strong. There you will find many locals from the neighbourhood, a sure sign to add any culinary address to the top of the list - one that will cost you just a few euros.

Friggitoria Vomero
Via Domenico Cimarosa 44
80129 Napoli

+39 081 578 3130

https://www.facebook.com/friggitoria.vomero

Menu: around 6 EUR

content.title: 100% Neapolitan dinner at Antica Capri

introduction.small: The trattoria is always full: a tell-tale sign of the popularity of this address with authentic cuisine and reasonable prices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 100% Neapolitan dinner at Antica Capri

paragraphs.text:
Opened by Crescenzo - father of 10 children - in 1968, the family restaurant, located nearby the central funicular, has had many lives before Rosario, one of his sons, took over the reins with his wife. Since then, Antica Capri is packed at each service.

Here, in rustic decor - the walls are adorned with copper pots, eclectic souvenirs and yellowed postcards -, the traditional Neapolitan gastronomy reveals its full scope. The menu highlights seafood products: scialatielli ai frutti di mare (thick pasta with seafood), risotto alla pescatora (fisherman's risotto) and linguine all'astice (lobster linguine). For pizza aficionados, the margherita is an ode to simplicity with sun-drenched tomatoes and melting mozzarella, drizzled with a dash of extra-virgin olive oil. Else, venture into a bold choice: the copious seafood pizza, or the eggplant, parmesan and provola calzone.

Don't wait to immerse yourself in the warm atmosphere of this unique place, where you are welcomed just like at home!

Trattoria e Pizzeria Antica Capri
Via Speranzella 110
80132 Napoli

+39 (0)81 038 3486

https://www.anticacapri.it/indexen.html

Menu: around 15 EUR

content.title: Cross the ancient city, north to south

introduction.small: Discover the famous Spaccanapoli, the ancient Roman street which splits the city in two in its historic centre, for a family outing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cross the ancient city, north to south

paragraphs.text:
In Spaccanapoli, plunge into one of the most characteristic and animated neighbourhoods of Naples' historic centre. Consisting, really, of only two streets, via Benedetto Croce and via San Biagio dei Librai, Spaccanapoli bisects the city. From each side, wander the narrow side streets and gaze upon the many palazzi, churches, cloisters and chapels, boutiques, arts and crafts shops, and trattorie.

You definitely need to stop at the Piazza del Gesù Nuovo and admire its monumental church of the same name, which dates from the 16th century. Built on the grounds of an ancient palace, the façade is adorned with small stones cut in a diamond shape and typical of the Renaissance style. The sobriety of the exterior stands in stark contrast with the lavish indoor areas, decorated with various frescoes. On the same square, you cannot miss the Spire of the Immaculate Conception, a majestic 30-metre-high white marble arrow that towers high above the rest.

Parrocchia Immacolata al Gesù Nuovo
(Gesù Nuovo church)
Piazza del Gesù Nuovo 2
80134 Napoli

http://www.gesunuovo.it/content/10012-la-chiesa.html

Obelisco dell'Immacolata
(Spire of the Immaculate Conception)
Piazza del Gesù Nuovo
80134 Napoli

content.title: Neapolitan Shopping

introduction.small: Indulge in Italian elegance in boutiques along the shoreline or from the more modestly priced shops in adjoining streets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Neapolitan Shopping

paragraphs.text:
Shopping in Naples mainly centres on two streets: via Toledo and via Chiaia. Built in 1536 to mark the limits of the old town from the part where Spanish troops were being stationed, Via Toledo now runs on 1.2 km from Piazza Dante and extends to the seafront. A pedestrian street between Piazza Carità and Piazza Trieste e Trento, it is as lively as you can imagine, a perfect place for a shopping spree, lined with big and small clothing and shoe stores at friendly prices.

As for Via Chiaia, hugging the waterfront, it is the chic showcase of fashion and luxury in Naples. Make a stop at Tramontano, shop dedicated to high end leather goods. There, you will also find any number of new designers and stylists. It is also the place to visit for lovers of antiques and home decor.

Tramontano
Via Chiaia 143
80121 Napoli

+39 (0)81 414 837

https://www.tramontano.it/en/

content.title: The custom-tailored island

introduction.small: If the Bay of Naples is a jewelled box, the island of Capri is the diamond within.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The custom-tailored island

paragraphs.text:
During your stay in Naples, plan to spend one or two days on the most beautiful island in its bay: Capri. Rugged landscapes cut through by stairways and glimmering turquoise waters have earned the island its international renown. After a short trip of between 45 and 1h20 minutes (if you choose a fast hydrofoil or a traditional ferry boat) to Marina Grande, the tramway carries you to the city of Capri. Its little "piazetta" is the true heart of the island, with its lively terraces and luxury boutiques. For swimming, south-facing Marina Piccola offers pretty little beaches and a sublime view of Capri's famous Faraglioni rock formations.A totally different ambience awaits you in the town of Anacapri. To get there, climb Marina Grande's 800-step Phoenician stairway. There, visit Axel Munthe's beautiful Villa San Michele (property of the State of Sweden), before roaming Anacapri's tiny side streets. Finally, visit the mythical marine-blue seaside cave Grotta Azzura, surrounded by beaches carved from the cliffs.

Tourist office
Piazzetta Ignazio Cerio 11
80073 Capri

+39 (0)81 837 5308

http://www.capritourism.com/en/index

content.title: Poetry and Art Nouveau at the Gambrinus

introduction.small: The indispensable location for fans of Art Nouveau and sfogliatelle, Campania's typical pastry.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Poetry and Art Nouveau at the Gambrinus

paragraphs.text:
"I want your whole light body to curve and arch like laughing Argentinian lips", wrote Gabriele d'Annunzio in the Cisalpine Sonnets, bending over his cup of coffee in an avant-garde Art Nouveau Gambrinus decor.
The most literary and historic café in Naples is situated on the Plazza del Plebiscito. It will delight fans of Oscar Wilde, Hemingway or Sartre, who all dipped their hot sfogliatella pastry stuffed with vanilla ricotta here (rum babas, almond pastries and biscotti all'amarenaare worthy contenders).
As a witness to the city's tormented history (it was deemed an anti-fascist lair and was closed under Mussolini), Gran Caffè Gambrinus has stood the test of time. The flower motifs and bright lights, as well as alabaster statues and paintings on the walls make it a perfect stop for food and espresso lovers.

Gran Caffè Gambrinus
Via Chiaia 1
Piazza Trieste e Trento 2
80132 Napoli

+39 (0)81 417 582

https://grancaffegambrinus.com

content.title: Encounter the Gods at the National Archaeological Museum

introduction.small: The Archaeological Museum of Naples houses the most important Greco-Roman collections in the world. A visit will refresh school memories of history and mythology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Encounter the Gods at the National Archaeological Museum

paragraphs.text:
One of the most important Greco-Roman collections in the world is gathered over three floors. A visit is akin to opening splendid textbooks of pages containing the gripping mosaic of Alexander the Great in battle against Darius III, and the Head of Caracalla (the Roman Emperor who ruled from 211 to 217). Antique sculptures have been exceptionally well preserved and pay a vibrant tribute to the great characters of mythology, like the Dancing Faun, Seated Hermes and the Farnese Hercules. You will be amazed by the sculpture of the punishment of Dirce, made of one block.

We can't forget the Callipygian Venus, which has stunned viewers for the last 23 centuries, or the amazing bronzes of runners from the Villa of Papyri in Herculaneum. There is also a beautiful collection of cameos, weapons, pottery, and jewellery. An appointment is necessary to see the museum's hidden collection of erotic objects and frescoes.

National Archaeological Museum of Naples
Piazza Museo Nazionale 19
80135 Napoli

+39 (0)81 442 2149

https://www.museoarcheologiconapoli.it/en/

content.title: Da Ciro a Mergellina, all of Naples in the kitchen

introduction.small: Quite simply the traditional restaurant most beloved by locals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Da Ciro a Mergellina, all of Naples in the kitchen

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of Posillipo hill, facing the fishing port, the very well-known Da Ciro a Mergellina mixes the sacred and the pagan upon its tables, not far from Mergellina's Santa Maria del Parto church. A welcoming and refined place in where Italian cuisine is being highlighted by the use of carefully selected raw materials and complemented by a large wine list.

The staff only has to cross the street to furnish the restaurant with its fresh fish. Of course, pizza and pasta are also on the menu, in classic recipes with mozzarella di bufala, fresh basil, tomatoes and other fresh and flavourful products... Service is very attentive around animated tables in which the show is as much in the dining room as on the plates.

All of Naples is felt, then, in an atmosphere that is at once alive and elegant.

Da Ciro a Mergellina
Via Mergellina 21
80122 Napoli

+39 (0)81 681 780

https://www.ciroamergellina.it/

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: Gran Caffè La Caffettiera, chic and Art Deco

introduction.small: Perfect spot to see and be seen in Naples, the establishment is known for the sophistication of its Art Deco setting, its pastries, and its cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gran Caffè La Caffettiera, chic and Art Deco

paragraphs.text:
The Gran Caffe la Caffettiera has long attracted celebrities, politicians and well-off Neapolitans.

With its early 20th-century style, the Gran Caffe is the ideal place to enjoy an espresso with pastries fresh from the oven each morning or an aperitif at sundown. Traditional coat racks, wood finishing, and warm lighting give this establishment a sophisticated aesthetic.

In the evenings, sit at the bar with the locals to enjoy a delicious cocktail. Head to the terrace during summer evenings with a glass of champagne to watch the city come to life. Among various treats, enjoy Sicilian pasta (eggplant, tomato, ricotta, basil), Nerano custard (typical Neapolitan dish with basil and/or mint and provolone) or some Neapolitan rice sartù (small rice timbale filled with green peas, parmesan, mozzarella, raw eggs and ground beef)… As you leave Gran Caffè, you will understand what the Neapolitan art of living is all about!

Gran Caffè La Caffettiera
Piazza dei Martiri 26
80121 Napoli

+39 (0)81 764 4243

https://www.grancaffelacaffettiera.com

content.title: Mermaid songs along the Amalfi coast

introduction.small: Preserved beaches and coves, terraces dotted with olive groves, citrus trees, vineyards, as well as remarkable sites: all on board for a getaway on the divine coast!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mermaid songs along the Amalfi coast

paragraphs.text:
A tour along the magnificent Amalfi coast, bordering the Gulf of Salerno, is a must. Ranked on UNESCO's World Heritage list, it is known for its rugged terrain and the variety of its landscapes. The legend says that the gods of Olympus would take the route between Bomerano and Nocelle, along the coast, when they wanted to hear the mermaids singing.

Amalfi's villages can be named like the beads on a rosary: Vietri sul Mare, the "capital of pottery"; Tramonti, the land of pizza chefs; Minori, surrounded by a heavenly bay; authentic Atrani, an escape from mass tourism… Make a stop in the Cetara and Maiori fishing harbours for their sandy beaches; then climb up to admire the fantastic panoramas of Capo d'Orso and Ravello, nestled 350 metres above the cobalt blue sea.

Your journey will inevitably take you to Sorrento, Positano and Amalfi, competing for the title of most beautiful gem on the coast. They are so exquisite you'll have a hard time choosing a favourite!

https://www.amalfitouristoffice.it/home.asp

content.title: Ristorante da Dora, simple pleasures

introduction.small: Nestled in a discreet alleyway of central Naples, this small family trattoria exalts seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ristorante da Dora, simple pleasures

paragraphs.text:
The Ristorante da Dora trattoria is locally acclaimed for its superb, rustic seafood dishes. Its two small dining rooms are decorated in a nautical theme.

Tables are spread with copious dishes such as savoury linguine alla Dora, served with lobster, mussels, and shrimp in a tomato sauce. Not to worry: bibs are provided. Also taste the spaghetti with clams, garlic, and parsley, and the fried crayfish. Other entries on the menu include fish risotto, grilled fresh calamari and haricot bean cakes. Ristorante de Dora attracts a loyal following among the locals and well-informed tourists with this simple but irresistible seafood selection, which is always served with a smile.

Open for lunch and dinner, the restaurant is tiny, so it is best to reserve in advance in order to be assured of a table. Once seated with delicious antipasti in hand, relax and enjoy traditional Neapolitan songs accompanied by acoustic guitar.

Ristorante da Dora
Via Ferdinando Palasciano 30
80122 Napoli

+39 081 680 519

https://www.ristorantedora.it/eng/index.html

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: La Ciliegina Lifestyle Hotel, red brick and tradition

introduction.small: Ten minutes by foot from the port of Naples, La Ciliegina Lifestyle Hotel bets of high-end authenticity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Ciliegina Lifestyle Hotel, red brick and tradition

paragraphs.text:
Situated 250 metres from the San Carlo Theatre and a few steps away from the Castel Nuovo, this hotel is recognisable by its facade of red brick. With a clever mix of historical architecture and modern appliances, the building really stands out in the centre of Naples. Its charming, immaculate interiors are brightened by special touches: golden chandeliers, large oak doors, bright red lamps, and printed fabrics. Just as opal-white, the 14 rooms are rich in contrasts, with deep blue fabrics, printed cushions, and artisanal furniture under high ceilings that give the whole a deliciously old-fashioned feel. The hydro-massage showers and whirlpool baths are installed in, and surrounded by, a world of grey marble. The beds are courtesy of the official supplier to the Swedish royal family. Settle into the large Jacuzzi on the rooftop terrace or lounge in the sun before having a cocktail, all while contemplating Naples and its sea of red tile rooftops.

La Ciliegina Lifestyle Hotel
Via Paolo Emilio Imbriani 30
80133 Napoli

+39 (0)81 971 8800

https://en.cilieginahotel.it/

Rooms: from 187 EUR

content.title: Il Comandante, table with a view

introduction.small: Il Comandante does justice to the Bay of Naples with high-quality creative Italian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Il Comandante, table with a view

paragraphs.text:
Installed on the 10th floor of the sublime Hotel Romeo and nestled within the former palace of a ship owner and mayor of Naples, Il Comandante is one of the best-rated starred restaurants in the city. Open for dinner only, the establishment is a must for whoever wishes to really discover Italian cuisine in all its diversity. Its superb menu is only equalled by the views over the bay.

Chef Salvatore Bianco creates fresh and refined Italian flavours. All products are of premium quality, and the chef endeavours to give his best in every single dish he prepares. Flavours are heightened, skilfully blended, and the end result is enhanced by various delicate touches. Diners have a choice between the tasting menu and delicious offerings from the regular menu. Example dishes include pear-ricotta mousse, grilled lobster with green apple and cucumber, mullet with scallops, mayo, plankton and fennel. This establishment also offers an impressive wine selection.

You can expect contemporary cuisine and highly professional service.

Il Comandante
Via Cristoforo Colombo 45
80133 Napoli

+39 081 604 1580

https://www.romeohotel.it/en/naples/

Menu: from 80 EUR

content.title: La Notizia: the temple of pizza

introduction.small: This temple of real Neapolitan pizza cultivates the richness of local products: Cetera tuna, Caserta pork sausage, Piennolo tomatoes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Notizia: the temple of pizza

paragraphs.text:
In the well-off Posillopo neighbourhood, chef Enzo Coccia raises pizza-making to the ranks of high art.

The green walls and the tomato-red chairs of pizzeria La Notizia 94 create a relaxed atmosphere that is interrupted only by the comings and goings of the staff. Pizzas cook for only 60 seconds in a brick oven fed by a special blend of beech and oak wood. Temperature is adjusted for each set of Margarita, Marinara, and Bianca pizzas. Enzo Coccia's secret weapon is his dough, enriched with just a hint of yeast, which rises for 12 hours in humidity-controlled fermentation chambers. Carefully leaving nothing to chance, the chef prepares the lightest, crispiest, and most savoury pizzas in the city. Clients are treated like old friends, in respect with the legendary Italian sense of hospitality.

To get here, take the tram to Vomero, and then head towards Posillopo.

La Notizia 53
Via Michelangelo da Caravaggio 53
80126 Napoli

+39 081 714 2155

La Notizia 94
Via Michelangelo da Caravaggio 94
80126 Napoli

+39 081 19 53 1937

https://www.pizzarialanotizia.com/en/

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Decumani, the 17th century made affordable

introduction.small: Plunge in the unique atmosphere of a high church authority's former residence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Decumani, the 17th century made affordable

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of old Naples, the Decumani is a former palace that used to house the private apartments of Sisto Riario Sforza, then the Archbishop of Naples and later Cardinal.

Built in the 17th century, this hotel of historic charm has a ballroom with arching ceilings, which sparkle with golden candelabras, and a shiny black grand piano. The antiques spilling out of the interiors of the Decumani are evidence of its illustrious past. The 22 rooms, on offer at a seductive price, are soberly and stylishly decorated, with ancient furniture, high windows, heavy curtains and waxed wooden floors.

After having taken your breakfast in the ballroom, explore the historical sites in the area. Walk to the beautiful Santa Chiara church and take the older streets of the neighbourhood to understand why UNESCO considers this area "the largest open-air museum in the world".

content.title: Costantinopoli 104, an urban oasis

introduction.small: Mixing history and contemporary style, Costantinopoli 104 offers custom-designed relaxation in the heart of a hectic city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Costantinopoli 104, an urban oasis

paragraphs.text:
A haven of peace and elegance, Costantinopoli 104 is tucked into a 19th-century palace in the centre of historic Naples.

With only 13 rooms and six suites, this boutique hotel boasts designer interiors, honey-toned parquet floors, and luxurious gardens that give a comforting impression of being at home. Mixing different styles, the rooms at Costantinopoli 104 seduce with warm tones, a history-soaked atmosphere, and contemporary luxury. Relax in a universe of contrasts between the white walls, stylish furniture, bright red cushions, and wood-framed mirrors. Cosy alcoves hide sofas and sometimes even sumptuous bathtubs. Situated in the garden, Costantinopoli 104's swimming pool is one of Naples' rare open-air pools. Don't miss out on the comfortable sitting room with a fireplace.

This hotel puts you in immediate proximity to myriad designer boutiques, restaurants, and historic sites.

content.title: Vesuvius National Park: enter the scene

introduction.small: 12 kilometres from Naples, go on an excursion that will please kids and adults alike: a live geology lesson!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vesuvius National Park: enter the scene

paragraphs.text:
Mount Vesuvius is seen under a beautiful morning light as a shadow, a doubt, a vague menace over the calm of the Bay of Naples. In this mythical setting, it is a dark jewel, a black diamond.

On its extremely fertile slopes, fruit trees and vineyards (including the famous Lachryma Christi of Vesuvius Neapolitan wine) produce in abundance. From the base, a 500-metres easy-access footpath takes you to the crater. As you climb up, you see the landscape changing, vegetation giving way to a dark and mineral counterpart, drenched in silence… Here you are: a breathtaking vista over the city and the Mediterranean spreads before your eyes. A guide will tell then you the story and many legends of this famously active volcano. Conquer this giant, appearing all so calm, for one of the best experiences of your stay.

content.title: The New Days of Pompeii

introduction.small: Bearing the traces of History's tragedy, the remains of Pompeii and Herculaneum are extraordinary time machines.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The New Days of Pompeii

paragraphs.text:
Unparalleled in history, the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 BC cast the daily life of two flourishing Roman cities, commercial Pompeii and residential Herculaneum, in ashes and mud.

Far from the gloomy image created by countless movies, the remains of Pompeii are first and foremost a terrific testimony of daily life during Ancient Rome.

Less than an hour away from Naples by train, you will be taken 2,000 years back to the heart of an antique city. Don't expect mountains of bodies lying around, only a few have been preserved from the erosion of time, displayed along with items and earthenware. The city appears to be strangely intact.

You can stroll around the high paved streets, enter small housing as well as the largest villas of rich merchants.

Theatres, shops and temples all present a more tactile and moving reality than any book or story would ever convey. Many frescoes, statues, and various objects have been transferred to the Archaeology Museum of Naples, a perfect place to learn more about the city's past..

content.title: Teatro di San Carlo, Farinelli's splendid echo

introduction.small: The lyric opera of San Carlo is a gold and silver shrine that instils opera scores with fresh radiance. Neapolitan magnificence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Teatro di San Carlo, Farinelli's splendid echo

paragraphs.text:
Constructed under Charles of Bourbon and inaugurated in 1737, the San Carlo is Naples' most important theatre. It is also the oldest lyric opera house in Europe that is still in use.

The greatest castrati of Naples, including the famous Farinelli and Giovanni Carestini, performed here during the 18th century. Entirely destroyed by a fire in 1816, it was reconstructed in less than a year by the Tuscan architect and stage designer Antonio Niccolini.

With ballets, operas and concerts, San Carlo now offers a rich and eclectic programme. Yet, the show also takes place elsewhere than on stage: dressed in velvety red and gold, the beauty of this sumptuous hall is striking. The ceiling's fresco spreads over the six floors of boxes adorned with glowing flares.

There is no need for you to be an opera buff to appreciate the setting. Guided tours are organised every day (except Wednesday, reserved to school groups). Do not miss the opportunity to enter one of Europe's most illustrious art scenes!

Teatro di San Carlo
Via San Carlo 98
80132 Napoli

+39 (0)81 797 2331

https://www.teatrosancarlo.it/en/

content.title: Capodimonte Museum: O Caravaggio!

introduction.small: The largest museum in Italy is visited for both its extraordinary collections and the sheer splendour of the place, offering special access to the Bourbon princes' royal place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Capodimonte Museum: O Caravaggio!

paragraphs.text:
Upon arrival, you will be captivated by the vastness of this 130-hectar park, where the splendid palazzo of Charles VII, King of Naples, stands. Friends and family love to gather in this hilly and lush place to play football, have a picnic or wander one of the 500 hiking trails.

Former home of the Bourbon dynasty, the striking pink stone building houses the museum and its priceless masterpieces. Let your footsteps guide you from room to room, where the grandeur of mirrors, crystal chandeliers and marble colonnades fade before the genius of the great masters: Bruegel the Elder, Jacopo de' Barbari, Artemisia Gentileschi and, of course, Caravaggio and his famous Flagellation of Christ…

The Farnese Collection and Neapolitan gallery compete in their ability to trace the history of painting, from the 13th to the 18th century.

Do not miss the royal apartments and their porcelain from the renowned manufactory established in 1743.

Far from the hustle and bustle of the city, take a moment to relax and enjoy a cultural walk in the countryside in one of the most beautiful Neapolitan sites.

Museo Capodimonte
Via Miano 2
80137 Napoli

+39 081 749 9111

https://www.museocapodimonte.beniculturali.it/information-en/

content.title: Castel Nuovo, symbol of the Gothic Renaissance

introduction.small: Among the city's many architectural gems, do not miss the surprising Castel Nuovo, built in the late Middle Ages, now an emblematic location.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castel Nuovo, symbol of the Gothic Renaissance

paragraphs.text:
Do not judge it by its name, the "New Castle" was thus named to differentiate it from nearby fortresses when built upon Charles of Anjou's request in 1279.

As you stroll around the historic centre, you'll notice its high castellated towers near the harbour, as well fortifications worthy of a fairy tale.

Cross the drawbridge : built in 1470 for Alfonso V of Aragon, a Renaissance-style white marble triumphal arch overlooks the buildings' entrance. The vaulted arch of the Baron room is another testimony of this king who championed the arts: the 28-metre high 16 stone arches make for a speechless architectural prowess. And what would a castle be without moats? Walk down the staircase leading to the Crocodile cell, where the enemies of the court were eaten alive…

Finally, save some breath to gain higher grounds on the terrace and enjoy the beautiful panorama over the harbour and the Vesuvius.

Castel Nuovo
Piazza Castello
80133 Napoli

+39 (0)81 795 7701

https://www.comune.napoli.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeBLOB.php/L/EN/IDPagina/1372

content.title: Cappella Sansevero Museum, take the Veil

introduction.small: In the Sansevero chapel, mystery, beauty and Baroque creativity dazzle visitors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cappella Sansevero Museum, take the Veil

paragraphs.text:
uilt in 1590 in the historic centre of Naples by Giovan Francesco di Sangro and converted into a family tomb by his son Alessandro in 1613, the Cappella San Severo, still referred to as Chiesa di Santa Maria della Pieta, enshrines numerous masterpieces in the Neapolitan Baroque style. All were commissioned by alchemist Raimondo di Sangro, prince of San Severo, who transformed his chapel into a masonic temple, and, in the crypt, made his infamous 'anatomical machines' encased.

Among the art pieces, two marble sculptures are curiously parallel to the skinless models in the crypt: the Cristo Velato (Veiled Christ) by Giuseppe Sanmartino and Pudicizia (Modesty) by Antonio Corradini, the artist first commissioned for the Veiled Christ who died after having completed only sketches.

The principle is identical for both art pieces: the marble veils, of an exquisite transparency, reveal and shape that which they were supposedly masking. Thus, the tortures of Christ and the pointed nipples of the modest woman seem all the more exposed.

Museo Cappella Sansevero
Via Francesco de Sanctis 19/21
80134 Napoli

+39 (0)81 551 8470

https://www.museosansevero.it/?lang=en

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Naples
content.introduction: Naples enjoys a typically Mediterranean climate. Summers are hot and dry, although sea breezes help to cool down the city. Winters are mild, with frequent rainy spells, usually short in duration, but marked occasionally by violent storms.

airports.title: Naples Capodichino International Airport
airports.description:
The Naples Capodichino International Airport is located about 6 kilometres (4 miles) north-east of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Naples and back
  • By car
    • Accessible via the highway that runs through Naples (A56 - Tangenziale).
    • There are four short-term parking facilities (P2, P3, P4 and P5) charging around EUR 3.50 per hour.
    • One drop-off area, free but limited to 10-minute parking.
    • One long-term facility (P1). EUR 9 for 12 hours, EUR 20 for 24 hours.
    • Several car rental companies have counters, located in the arrivals area.
  • By shuttle
    • Alibus (www.anm.it) operates shuttle bus services connecting the airport with Napoli Centrale train station, every 10 to 20 minutes from 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. One-way ticket: EUR 5.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks just outside the terminals. The fixed fare to Piazza Municipio is EUR 18 (for a maximum of four passengers with luggage).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +39 (0)81 789 6111
  • Website: www.aeroportodinapoli.it/homepage

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Naples
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Naples each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 6:Epiphany (Feast of Befana) (national holiday)
events.description: For all Italians, the 6<sup>th</sup> of January is the day when the benevolent white witch Befana, who predates Santa Claus in Italy, arrives on her broomstick with presents and candy for all children who have been good during the year, or a lump of coal if they have been bad!

events.title: Week leading to Easter:Holy Week (Settimana Santa) (national holiday)
events.description: Holy week takes place one week before Easter. It is an opportunity for several religious events in Naples.

events.title: April 25:Liberation Day (Festa della Liberazione) (national)
events.description: Each year, this holiday commemorates the end of World War II in Italy. It is an opportunity for celebrations and parades throughout the city.

events.title: May 1:Labour Day (Festa del lavoro) (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates Labour Day throughout Italy, with various art groups setting up events in the city's historic centre: shows, workshops, street theatre…

events.title: June 2:Republic Day (Festa della Repubblica) (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the national referendum voted on this day in 1946, when the Italian people chose a republic instead of a monarchy. In Naples, as in the rest of Italy, celebrations include official ceremonies, a military parade, fireworks, concerts and street parties.

events.title: August 15:Assumption (Assunzione della Beata Vergine Maria)(national holiday)
events.description: To celebrate the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, masses and processions are held in her honour in churches and streets throughout the historic centre.

events.title: September 19: Feast of San Gennaro (local event)
events.description: The feast day of Naples' patron saint is the most important religious festival of the year. The faithful flock to the Duomo to see whether San Gennaro's blood, stored in vials at the cathedral, will liquefy, a recurring miracle that is believed to indicate the saint's intervention, thus saving Naples from wars, epidemics and natural disasters over the centuries. Misfortunes having struck the city in years when the blood failed to liquefy include the bubonic plague in 1527 and the major earthquake in 1980. A mass is held at the cathedral, followed by an elaborate procession through the streets of Naples.

events.title: November 1:All Saint's Day (Ognissanti) (national holiday)
events.description: All Saints Day is celebrated throughout Italy with various religious events, especially in the churches of Naples.

events.title: November 4:National Unity and Armed Forces Day (Giorno dell'Unità Nazionale) (national holiday)
events.description: For this official commemoration of Italian reunification and the end of the First World War, military parades are held across the city.

events.title: November–December: Christmas Market (local event)
events.description: During this period, Via San Gregorio and the adjoining streets are taken over by stalls of craftspeople who make and sell figurines of the Holy Family, the Three Kings as well as all other accessories required for creating manger scenes, a vibrant local tradition.

events.title: December 26:Santo Stefano (national holiday)
events.description: This Italian holiday commemorates the birth of Saint Stephen. Traditionally, this day is dedicated to family time, with large and festive meals taking place.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Naples like everywhere in Italy, a service charge (servizio) is usually included in the bill at restaurants. If the service is exceptional, you can certainly leave a few extra euros. Some restaurants also apply a cover charge (pane e coperto, literally "bread and cutlery"), which is not considered as a gratuity. You should therefore make sure beforehand that tip and cover charge are included in the bill!
